aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Analysis - Piper PA 30 Fuel Starvation Incident
The accident occurred in Kalispell, Montana.
The accident occurred on June 25, 2014, at 17:00 Local time.
The aircraft involved was a Piper PA 30.
The defining event of the accident was fuel starvation.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was WPR14LA269.
The aircraft registration was N7350Y.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
The accident resulted in 2 minor injuries.
The commercial pilot reported the right engine lost power during takeoff.
The aircraft was approximately 10 feet above the ground when the right engine lost power.
The aircraft veered right away from the runway after the engine lost power.
The pilot immediately switched fuel tanks after the engine lost power.
The pilot raised the landing gear after the engine lost power.
The pilot feathered both propellers after the engine lost power.
The aircraft entered approximately an 80-degree right bank.
The pilot applied full left aileron and rudder to level the aircraft.
The aircraft was nearly level just before it contacted the ground.
The aircraft came to rest approximately 500 feet off the right side of the runway.
The right engine separated from the fuselage during the accident sequence.
The pilot shut off the fuel valves after the accident.
The pilot did not recall which position the fuel selectors were set to for takeoff.
Postaccident examination of the airframe revealed no anomalies that would have precluded normal operation.
Postaccident examination of the right engine revealed no anomalies that would have precluded normal operation.
Postaccident examination revealed the main fuel tanks appeared to be empty.
Postaccident examination revealed the auxiliary tanks appeared to be almost full.
The auxiliary tanks have a total capacity of 30 gallons.
The pilot reported taking off with a total fuel quantity of 30 gallons.
Most of the usable fuel was in the auxiliary tanks.
The airplane flight manual states that fuel selectors should be selected "on" to the main fuel tanks for takeoff.
The pilot likely followed the takeoff procedures in the flight manual.
Following the takeoff procedures likely led to the fuel starvation of the right engine.
The Pilot's Operating Handbook preflight check included visually checking each tank's fuel quantity on the gauge.
The Pilot's Operating Handbook preflight check included visually checking the fuel quantity in each tank during the walkaround inspection.
The pilot likely did not adequately follow the preflight check procedures before the flight.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Kalispell, Montana

## Date & Time: 
June 25, 2014, 17:00 Local

## Aircraft:
Piper PA 30

## Defining Event:
Fuel starvation

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
WPR14LA269

## Registration:
N7350Y

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
2 Minor

## Analysis

The commercial pilot reported that, during takeoff for the cross-country flight, the right engine lost power. The airplane, which was about 10 ft above the ground, then veered right away from the runway. The pilot immediately switched fuel tanks, raised the landing gear, and feathered both propellers. Subsequently, the airplane entered about an 80-degree right bank, and the pilot was able to get the airplane nearly level, applying full left aileron and rudder, just before it contacted the ground. The airplane came to rest about 500 ft off the right side of the runway. During the accident sequence, the right engine separated from the fuselage. After the accident, the pilot shut off the fuel valves; he did not recall which position the fuel selectors were set to for takeoff. Postaccident examination of the airframe and right engine did not reveal any anomalies or failures that would have precluded normal operation.

Postaccident examination of the airplane revealed that the main fuel tanks appeared to be empty but that the auxiliary tanks, which have a total capacity of 30 gallons, appeared to be almost full. The pilot reported taking off with a total fuel quantity of 30 gallons; therefore, most of the usable fuel was in the auxiliary tanks. The airplane flight manual states that, for takeoff, the fuel selectors should be selected "on" to the main fuel tanks. It is likely that the pilot followed these procedures, which led to the fuel starvation of the right engine. The Pilot's Operating Handbook preflight check included a step to visually check each tank's fuel quantity on the gauge and to visually check the fuel quantity in each tank during the walkaround inspection. Based on the evidence, it is likely that the pilot did not adequately follow these procedures before the flight.
